Authors:
Martin Schnittler, Oleg Shchepin, Mikhail V. Okun, Daria A.
Erastova, Yuri K. Novozhilov
Title:
Nivicolous species of Diderma (Myxomycetes) seen through the
lens of DNA barcoding: which taxonomic concept fits best?
Keywords:
diversity, Myxogastria, nivicolous myxomycetes, protein
elongation factor EF1A, 18S rRNA gene
Abstract:
It still remains unclear to what extent the morphological
species concept reflects the true diversity in myxomycetes. The
nivicolous species of the genus Diderma are difficult to identify, and
there are several competing views on their delimitation based on
morphological characters. We barcoded 545 specimens across the Northern
Hemisphere to look which of the current taxonomic treatments is better
supported by molecular data. The results support a splitting approach
which distinguishes six taxa: D. alpinum, D. europaeum, D. fallax, D.
meyerae, D. microcarpum and D. niveum. In addition, a seventh taxon, D.
kamchaticum, is described as new for science. Partial 18S rRNA gene
sequences serving as DNA barcodes provided enough resolution to
differentiate all seven taxa with a 99.1% similarity threshold. A
two-gene phylogeny (18S rRNA and EF1A) supported monophyly of these
taxa. These clades form reproductively isolated units: recombination
between 18S rRNA and EF1A sequence variants occurs within, but not
between these groups. This allows to combine the morphological,
phylogenetic and biological species concepts for the studied group.
Given the high environmentally caused variation in sporocarp characters,
the morphological differentiation of these taxa remains difficult, but
18S rRNA sequences provide clear signatures that can be used as
barcodes. We therefore suggest to recognize seven nivicolous Diderma
species, and give taxonomic descriptions and a determination key.
